content.body: Hixie, http://www.w3.org/Bugs/Public/show_bug.cgi?id=13551 was filed by an implementer -- you really want it assigned to contributor⊙wo?

TabAtkins, it's *possible* to play a game based on WASD+mouselook without a mouse lock, if the mouse sensitivity isn't really low.  You just have to do some 360s every time the mouse gets too close to the edge of the screen.
it's ... really not, heh
like, sure, you can drive a car that only turns left, but ... not really
I didn't say it would be *fun*.
If you don't want it to be fun, just use the arrow keys for turning (and alt+arrows for strafe) then you don't need mouselook at all
question about the Do Not Track feature/spec, for anybody who knows
if I send a DNT: 1 opt-out header to "first-party" site, does that mean it also can't do any "collection, retention, and use of all data related  to the request and response"?
or does it mean only any third-party sites with embedded content on that page can't do collection, retention, and use of all data related to the request and response?
it's not clear from the spec
http://tools.ietf.org/html/draft-mayer-do-not-track-00
the spec says, "In processing a request that includes an OPT-OUT header, a server MUST NOT perform THIRD-PARTY TRACKING"
but it doesn't say the first-party site can't do "tracking" (= collection, retention, and use of all data related to the request and response)
and given a request with a DNT: 1 header, how does a site know whether it's a third-party site or a first-party site?
or does the UA only send the DNT: 1 header to third-party sites but not not first-party sites?
Hixie: you recall why websocket has sec-websocket-origin rather than just origin?
zcorpan: Didn't it have something to do with XHR originally
Then I have a feeling that the real reason got removed by some other change and the sec-websocket- bit got cargo culted in
Or stayed in for cargo-cult reasons
maybe websocket's origin header predated the other origin header

Some discussion about the organization of DOM specs

DOM Core
and then when I make a suggestion they do not answer
further slowing progress

smaug____, I was wondering, do you agree with all the DOM 3 Events stuff?
smaug____, because some of those replies to Last Call comments are rather, well, odd
which one in particularly
e.g. on DOM features
"odd" replies are the norm in standardization, apparently :)
or changing scroll to a UIEvent
which contradicts e.g. CSSOM View
and implementations
smaug____, so you support the decisions?
Let's say so that I'm ok with the decisions
wow
how does changing scroll to UIEvent contradicts with CSSOM ?
it says to use Event
but that event overview is meaningless anyway
what matters is what interface is used when dispatching
the way events are defined in DOM Level 3 Events is rather laughable compared to how dispatching events is defined in other specifications
(of topic,  HTML spec and Web DOM code contradict with implementations quite often )
usually with good reason
not "to make this table look pretty"
not very often with  good reason
but I'm ok change scroll back to event
I just don't really care whether it is UIEvent or Event
well you disagree with the reason sometimes
but making it UIEvent because the spec's organization is cleaner then is nonsense
than*
that wasn't shepazu's reason to make scroll UIEvent
I might even like if most of the event in browsing context were UIEvents
since those give easy access to window
s/event/events/
smaug____, where does DOM Core contradict specifications btw without good reason?
smaug____, euh, implementations
annevk: (I assume that depends what you mean by "good reasons" e.g. removing attr nodes might not be considered "good reasons")
smaug____, cause I thought people were on board with Node : EventTarget, Attr no longer being a node, etc.
those are ok.
ÍMO
CDATA removal probably isn't
at least there hasn't been any good proposal how to fix the problems removing CDATA causes
(related to serialization )
oh, hmm, normalize() is removed
why
sicking has a proposal and there's a patch implementing CDATA removal in Gecko
I know Ms2ger has the patch to remove CDATA from Gecko
smaug____, presumably normalize() is either not implemented widely or lacks good use cases
wait
if CR LF is always normalized on submitting
text/plain can be parsed reliably
with respect to form submission

Hi
what's the definition of "visual", "tactile" and "bitmap" media type as used in http://www.w3.org/TR/css3-mediaqueries/ ?
does "visual" include "tty"? Or does "bitmap" include print?
no
types are exclusive
see CSS 2.1
ahh... right...
I just googled the terms and found CSS2.1 specs: http://www.w3.org/TR/CSS2/media.html
media queries 3.1 will prolly fix this
well fix in the sense that it will define both media types and media features and not defer to CSS 2.1 for the former
why "resolution" property accepts only dpi and dpcm units?
why not ppi?
what's the difference with dpi?
so for screen media type, dpi is treated like ppi?
I thought that DPI should be only used for printed media, where you have actual dots
I think so
maybe suggest on www-style that it is clarified
although I'm the editor I don't really know much about these units
CSS3 media queries specification says that resolution may accept only dpi and dpcm units and that resolution property applies to bitmap media types
now CSS2 specs defines bitmap media types as:
print, projection, screen and tv
I guess this means that DPI should be treated as PPI
at least on screen
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dots_per_inch#Computer_monitor_DPI_standards
yay, WHATWG Blog has >6000 subscribers per Google Reader
now I'm confused, how windows can <<set default display "DPI" to 96 PPI>>? Isn't this value depended on monitor size and resolution?
hmm didn't know there's a blog, make that 6001
well, >6001
jarek: They're independent of physical inches
jarek: I'm pretty sure that's due to a lack of monitor dpi api's
AryehGregor, there were several comments on your blog post that did not get approved thus far
AryehGregor, I approved them
so there are actually three units: DPI, logical PPI and physical PPI?
nevermind, this thing makes no sense
I will just hard-code in my code that PPI equals DPI, hopefully no one will notice :P

There's the number of RGB cells per inch on your LCD screen, and the number of pixels of data that the computer sends to the display per cell (hence per inch), and the number of pixels of data that the computer uses to represent objects measured in inches (or in fractions of inches, e.g. points)
plus any scaling factors the software wants to add
Also, the length of an inch will change if you travel at relativistic speeds
So it's quite hard to be consistent about measurements
Philip`: if iPad's specification says that it has 132 PPI screen (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_displays_by_pixel_density), how do I target this or any higher resolution with media queries?
will this work?
"@media screen and (min-resolution: 132dpi)"
Haven't got a clue
jarek: why don't you just test against it? Do you have an ipad?
benjoffe_: no, it's overpriced

(only the length of an inch in a different frame of reference. So not really a problem if you are looking at your computer in a spaceship travelling at 0.98c, but perhaps worth thinking about if you are building an intergalactic Oxford Circus and want the adverts to work for passers by)
Seems complex enough that the only reliable method is to test it (or copy from someone who's tested it)
vmware + osx + ios emulator
but I guess that this will be the only reliable way to verify it

(requires osx)

great, I have the developer license
Yes, I was only really thinking of special relativity. It's always easier to pretend gravity doesn't exist

it should be the same
yes I would be quite surprised if there was a difference there
Either the browser ignores the system, or the system lies to the browser, and the latter case wouldn't inspire much confidence that things aren't lying in other ways too

Oh, I thought it was so that the platform wasn't tainted with poor users
:(, my g+ account was suspended
it seems that the fact that i've been using `timeless` as my name for more than half my life (and my entire professional carrer) including IRL wasn't expected behavior
Myself, I didn't try
it's pretty ironic that google said that privacy is a priorty on g+, then immediately violates people's privacy by trying to force them to reveal their name
"well that was quick"
they said privacy was a priority?
everyone says that
it looks like iPad does not support resolution media query at all
those are silly anyway :)
iPads?
but there is "-webkit-device-pixel-ratio" media query, is it the same thing?
jarek: no, that's the number of physical pixels per css pixel
which for ipad/iphone3 is 1, for iphone4 is 2
jarek: what would you do w/ a resolution media query
other than poorly support every device you've never met
has only recently found one site which didn't suck wrt discrimination
cheers to misapplication of the word "discrimination"
(it was Fandango fwiw, they let me choose Mobile, BB app, or Normal)
zewt: you don't think that a service which forces users to get subpar content just because it thinks they want it is discriminating against those users?
timeless: well, I expect resolution media query to be widely supported in the near future, that's why I would like to implement it in my app sooner than later
no, i think that's using a loaded word to make something sound worse than it is
it's pretty bad
if i'm not allowed to participate in something
then how is that not discrimination?
It seems like the usual attitude is "I want my page to do something special on iPhones, how do I write a media query to target iPhones?", which is effectively an obfuscated form of browser sniffing
further, segregated busing in some cases still allowed you to ride the same buses
you just got stuck in the back
getting second or third class service on a bus was still service
jarek: does anything in media queries account for the fact that the font and layout size you want depends on the device, and not soley the dpi?
that's what we're getting on the internet
that sure sounds like discrimination to me
Philip`: indeed
eg. a phone is typically much higher resolution than a desktop monitor, much smaller, and viewed much closer
the resolution is only part of the story
anyway, as dbaron recently pointed out on www-style (?)
(Have any browsers started lying to media queries yet, in order to receive iPhone-targeted content?)
it's easy to get media queries wrong when you reach boundary conditions
Philip`: not sure about media queries
but i know that browsers have lied to receive iPhone content in other cases/ways
and i certainly expect it to happen soon enough
zewt: so, which part of my logic is flawed which makes my use of the word offensive to you?
<timeless> other than poorly support every device you've never met <- you called that discrimination, when it's the opposite of discrimination: behaving generically (even if not always usefully)
oh
they don't do that
they don't behave generically
that's what i was responding to
they either give out good content or crap
and you can only get good content if you pay the <iPhone-x> fee
`We only allow whites to sit in the front of buses, anyone who we've never met can since in the back`

There must be a better of solving the browser-sniffing problem (since clearly people often want to do that rather than querying capabilities) - given N browser/device combinations, authors want to select some subset, then new browsers/devices developed afterwards want to insert themselves into some selection of subsets (while still being uniquely identifiable themselves by later authors)
without needing identifiers that perpetually grow in length (like UA strings)
Philip`: generally speaking `let the user pick` works well for me
it certainly makes me happy
There must be some kind of maths that would support that sort of subsetting
have you used any of the ClearType configurator?
s/tor/tors/
(subpixel-antialiasing)
you show the user a couple of pictures and let them choose the one they like
The thing that asks "which of these three samples looks best"?
yeah
i don't want to undergo an eye exam every time i go to a new site, heh
i'm willing to do it
i'd certainly be happy to have a button at the bottom of each site which lets me undergo such an exam
"ask the user" is always a useful fallback but should always be a fallback
it's fine w/ me for sites to guess wrong as long as they let me choose
but most of the sites i see don't do that
my favorite is the *idiotic* news sites which when i am sent directly to an article
... redirect me to the front of their mobile site
because *obviously* i didn't want to read the article i visited!
heh
generally if i click a link and it doesn't go to what i clicked, i just leave
most commonly sites that go "well, you clicked on something explicitly, but we're going to ignore you and show you an ad/ask you to sign up/ask you to do the raindance/whatever first"
i need to get google to let me say `don't ever show content from this service again`

but ...
it often will show it in searches, but not always (seemingly at random)
yeah, sadly i use google news
i think for that i need to use the special configurator box or the impossible to use on my touch-based-device heisendropdown
i couldn't stand google news, because it seemed to refresh itself automatically all the time, so it always showed up highlighted in firefox as a "new tab"
(which insists on not being clickable)
hrm
it does refresh automatically
but you must be using some extension because firefox doesn't do that to me
i was
i'm not right now since i stopped using tabmixplus, but it's very useful
pages should never auto-refresh, that's just obnoxious
you don't want gmail to autorefresh?
hrm, you clearly don't use web-irc
that's ajax updating, it doesn't refresh the entire page
tomato tomato?
which is what gnews seemed to do, at least at the time
reloading the entire page is far different than a lightweight ajax update
how?
reloading the entire page could mean you could retrieve old versions from cache
(which can be useful)
how? it's sort of the ... point of ajax, heh
(only in part, of course)
if 99% of a page is content
then i'm not quite sure i'd buy that using ajax would actually mean much less load than a traditional page load
then you can update the content unintrusively
eg. greader
volkmar, if you specify trim on password, I don't really see why it shouldn't trim
annevk: why would someone trim a password?
to make copy and paste work better
if you don't allow spaces anyway
annevk: i don't think we should allow trimming passwords, that's really dangerous
dangerous?
google strips whitespace from passwords
annevk: if I type " foobar " in a password field and they I want to login and I can't...
I'm afraid it could be used without really realizing some side effects
how could you register such a password to begin with if they trim consistently and do not allow whitespace?
would seem like a very arbitrary special case to not support it
<input trim> UI could just mean you cannot type spaces at the beginning and end of your input
annevk: My concern might be the *if*
jgraham, then they would have problems with their JavaScript-based solution as well
or with any restrictions on password for that matter, which certainly are around

If you want to support accidental whitespace included around passwords, it'd be just as easy to do the trimming on the server (and then you could check both the trimmed and untrimmed passwords, in case the spaces really are part of the password)

conversely (though this is all very contrived and I don't see either ever happening in reality) someone might have their site trim spaces when storing a password, and use <input trim> to trim when entering, and not realize the *lack* of side effects due to arbitrary special cases
annevk: in general, altering the passwords value seems a wrong idea to me
yeah, any sanitization really needs to be enforced server side
not doing that is just plain stupid
zewt: fwiw...
i think it was canada post
but one of the sites was very anal about its login form `do not remember password`
well, doing trimming client-side can make it clearer that it's happening (though in practice it probably doesn't matter whether the user is aware of it or not, in the case of passwords)
the reset account password form was *not* anal
so you could remember the password there...
so... yes... it's trivially to be stupid and inconsistent!
s/ly//
yeah, it absolutely doesn't matter to users what you do to the password
quasirelatedly, we need a real password-storage API
they don't need to know that you're storing a sha256 hash instead of the actual password
annoying how so many sites break or semi-break browser password storage
how would a password-storage api help?
firefox insists on remembering my old bugzilla password
sites would just demand to disable it, or break it, or flood it with crap
well, there are two problems, i think: remembering passwords from login forms, and ajax logins
the former is what usually works, but sometimes does not; don't know why in the particular cases, but it'd be nice for that to be more reliable
the latter almost never works; it would be nice if it could
the former doesn't work when sites actively try to break it
the easiest way is to add the attribute that says `please break password manager`
i rarely see that, usually it's just unawareness of it
as far as i'm concerned sites should never have the ability to do that
the second easiest way is to not have a <form> containing the password field
(and then use js to shift it into the form/submission)
google passwords are regularly out of date for me, too
odd, i've never hit that problem
it just never offers to store the newly-entered password
but google is weird and it doesn't happen everywhere
i'm pretty sure firefox has offered to update my password for google
will have to check sometime
gmail fills in the password fine, for example, but if i open gapps management, that one's wrong
you know you can `easily` `fix` it by opening the password list and deleting the one for the gapps site
(ideally you'd be able to use Larry to fix it, but he never grew that feature)
anyway, it would be nice for ajaxy logins to have the ability to integrate with password management; right now they don't at all
well
all they have to do is use <form> <input> <input type=password>
as long as they have a handler on the <form> to trap onsubmit and send it where they need
they can absolutely integrate with password management
but if the form is never actually submitted as a form, firefox will never offer to store it
you sure?
how would it know?
ajax logins typically cancel form submission entirely (if form submit happens at all), so it can do it some other way
reddit seems to do login async and has never had problems remembering my login details
on chrome
don't know what reddit does
data:text/html,<form action="data:text/plain," onsubmit="alert(1); return false"><input id=name><input id=pass type=password><input type=submit>
isn't working 100%, but it's definitely asking to remember my password
alert(1) in an event handler is probably going to do weird things
although, perhaps noscript is suppressing js entirely :)
data:text/html,<form action="data:text/plain," onsubmit="console.log('xxx'); return false"><input id=name><input id=pass type=password><input type=submit>
doesn't prompt
(for me, in ff6)
data:text/html,<form action="data:text/plain," onsubmit="return false"><input id=name><input id=pass type=password><input type=submit>
it shouldn't--the form submission was cancelled, after all, why would it?
prompts for me in Nightly (different profile, no noscript)
shrugs
it is here
why are you setting 'id' on the form inputs? Should be name
what version of firefox are you using?
benjoffe_: because i can :)
as far as firefox can tell the submission was aborted, it'd be strange for it to offer to remember the password at that point
fwiw i only have add-on compatibility reporter and https-everywhere
timeless: forms remember and post the 'name' attribute, if you want to play nice with password managers use it
benjoffe_: my point is that even this contrived thing *does* play nicely with password managers
at least, it does w/ my Nighty
s/y$/ly/
wants to know why it isn't w/ zewt 's
that's surprising, they must be getting better
zewt: firefox --no-remote -P
i'm suggesting that offering to remember the password in the above code is wrong
well, it is remembering it
and remember, the offer isn't a modal dialog
so the user can safely ignore it
or say `why thank you for offering`
heh

Error: uncaught exception: [Exception... "'Can't add a login with a null or empty hostname.' when calling method: [nsILoginManager::addLogin]"  nsresult: "0x8057001e (NS_ERROR_XPC_JS_THREW_STRING)"  location: "JS frame :: resource:///components/nsLoginManagerPrompter.js :: <TOP_LEVEL> :: line 853"  data: no]

that just looks like it doesn't care for data:

Is this too snarky?  "This is an excellent opportunity for those who believe that the W3C is a good place to develop specs to show their willingness to improve the web.  All it would take is a modest amount of effort to submit the spec for W3C publication, and of course in their view, this would be beneficial because the W3C is a good place to publish specs.  I wait with interest for one of the many people who have expressed concern about the
editing spec not being at the W3C to spend the necessary time themselves to fix the problem, rather than expecting others to do it."

doesn't see it as snarky

i fully expect them to ignore you :)

yeah, but it takes a lot less time of course

Does HTML5 define somewhere how HTML tags are supposed to interact with context-sensitivity in Unicode characters?
I.e. http://stackoverflow.com/questions/7069247/css-formating-cursive-word-breaks-it
mercator: That's a CSS issue, actually.
I thought at least Firefox was able to apply colours to characters without breaking apart ligatures etc
Should be able to, yes.
My Firefox on Linux does do that with that example
(Opera doesn't)
TabAtkins: Is it? It does mention things like right-to-left embedding. Isn't this similar? The actual CSS being applied doesn't really matter. Should a tag break ligatures?
mercator: In general, the answer is no, it shouldn't.  Whether or not implementations support it properly is a different question.
we don't define things in that detail
it's implementation quality atm
much like line-breaking
Hmmm, I suppose character selection in fonts *is* more CSS than HTML... And indeed, implementations are rather different.
